Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce the total by way of premiums collected by (1) Irish insurance companies and (2) British insurance companies based in Ireland in each of the past three years; and the proportion of this amount invested in private housing by Irish and British companies respectively.
asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce the proportion of premiums collected by Irish based British insurance companies which are reinvested in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating) Justin Keating
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating)
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 120 and 121 together.

Particulars of annual life assurance and non-life insurance premiums collected in Ireland by Irish and non-Irish companies up to 1970 inclusive may be obtained from the Summary of Statements of Assurance Business published annually by my Department, copies of which are in the Library. Figures for 1971 which will be published shortly are Irish companies, £21.9 million for life insurance and £7 million for non-life; British companies, £17.6 million life insurance and £26.4 non-life.

As regards investment here by insurance companies, only a part of the money received in premiums is available for investment and, accordingly, it has been the practice to calculate investments, not as a proportion of premiums, but as a proportion of the insurance funds. While exact figures are not available, the proportion of funds invested in Ireland by Irish and British life offices is over 70 per cent in both cases. Figures for non-life, which are, of course, much less substantial, are not known. Investment by insurance companies in private housing in the four years 1969-70 to 1972-73 has been £6.77 million, £6.77 million, £7.91 million, and £6.86 million.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mortgage Broking Firm Charges.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will introduce legislation as a matter of urgency (a) to control effectively the activities of mortgage broking firms with particular reference to commissions and other charges made by these firms in respect of house mortgages and (b) to provide for full disclosure of all interest and other charges made by second mortgage companies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating) Justin Keating
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating)
Speaker.P: Charges made by mortgage broking firms come within the scope of the Prices Acts and accordingly such firms are required under the Prices and Charges (Notification of Increases) Orders, 1973 to give me two months' notice of any proposed increase in their charges. I have also power to fix maximum charges in respect of such firms. I have no evidence to indicate that it is necessary to introduce legislation to control the activities of these firms or to provide for the disclosure of the information mentioned by the Deputy.

asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if, in view of his decision not to introduce legislation banning trading stamps, as recommended by the National Prices Commission, he proposes to allow a company (name supplied) to open catalogue discount stores in this country similar to those recently opened in the UK.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating) Justin Keating
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating)
Speaker.P: It is not correct that the National Prices Commission now recommend the banning of trading stamps.

They have stated in their report for May, 1973, that there would be technical difficulties in providing legislation to ban trading stamps and they recommend instead that the stamp company should be compelled to raise the cash sum for which a book of stamps can be redeemed and that my approval should be received in advance of any proposed increase in the number of books of stamps required for any goods.
There is no provision in existing legislation requiring official approval for the opening of the type of store to which the Deputy refers.

asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if the present system of trading cheques has been investigated by his Department; if so, if he is satisfied that consumer interest in this matter is fully safeguarded and that the interest rates are reasonable under present legislation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating) Justin Keating
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating)
Speaker.P: The National Prices Commission are having a study carried out of the comparative cost of credit, including trading cheques. When the results of this study are available, I will then decide whether I should take any action in the matter.
asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce the average interest rates charged by HP companies; and if he will introduce legislation to fix the maximum interest rate which may be charged.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating) Justin Keating
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Keating)
Speaker.P: The nominal interest rates charged by the larger finance houses and by the licensed banks was 10½ per cent-11½ per cent in the four quarters up to March, 1973. Because the amount lent is reducing over the repayment period the actual rate of interest is almost twice the nominal rate. Information about the rates charged by the smaller companies is not available but as the rates are competitive they are unlikely to deviate very much from the market rates.

I have power to control the rates of interest charged for hire purchase but these charges cannot be considered in isolation from the interest rates for other types of consumer credit and I am not yet in a position to say whether it would be desirable to control them.

asked the Minister for Education if there is any evidence to show that in modern educational trends the opportunities for the talented child are increasing while opportunities for the undermotivated and less able student are on the decrease.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: I have no evidence to suggest that educational opportunities for the undermotivated or less able student are on the decrease. Indeed, the opposite is rather the case.

In our own country, as in most other countries, the case of the young person who, for one reason or another, has learning difficulties is the subject of continuing observation and research. Pupil guidance services, remedial teaching and special aid in other forms are being provided on an increasing scale for such pupils.
asked the Minister for Education if he has any plans to establish a school welfare division within his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: I have not at present any plans to establish a school welfare division within my Department but it is a matter which is receiving my consideration.
asked the Minister for Education the rate of contribution to be paid towards the cost of erecting a national school; and if the contribution varies from one county to another.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: My Department's Rules for National Schools provide that the normal grant for the erection, extension or improvement of a primary school building is two-thirds of the cost, the local contribution being one-third. There is provision, however, for the payment of grants at a rate higher than two-thirds of the cost if circumstances warrant it. There is no set rate of local contribution as between one county and another.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Heating and Cleaning.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will increase the allowance for the heating and cleaning of national schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The provision in the Estimates for my Department for the current financial year does not allow for any increase in these grants. The question of their being increased in the financial year 1974/75 will be considered in connection with the preparation of the Estimates for that year.

asked the Minister for Education if he considers that the primary school situation in the Ranelagh area of Dublin is satisfactory; and, if not, if he will state the steps that are being taken to remedy the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: No representations have been received in my Department in regard to primary school facilities in the Ranelagh area, and my information is that there is adequate accommodation, in schools within the parish or convenient to the parish, to meet requirements.
asked the Minister for Education if he has any plans to provide an extension for the primary school at Newcastle, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: It is proposed to add five extra classrooms and a general purposes room to the existing primary school at Newcastle, County Dublin. The school manager has been authorised to employ his own architect to prepare sketch plans for the scheme.

asked the Minister for Education if he will indicate in respect of proposals for the amalgamation of primary schools the number which have been abandoned or not sanctioned by his Department in the past three months.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: It is my policy to ensure that an opportunity is provided for full discussion with all the interests concerned before a decision to amalgamate national schools is taken. The provision of such opportunity for discussion, and further review, if necessary, instead of insistence on amalgamation by a particular date, does not, in my view represent an abandonment of any relevant proposal.
No proposal has been finally abandoned in the past three months. Neither has my Department refused to sanction during that period any proposal for amalgamation where there was local agreement for it.
asked the Minister for Education whether it is proposed to erect a new national school at Dromina, Rathluirc, County Cork; and, if so, when he expects that work on the building will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: It is proposed to erect a new national school at Dromina Rathluirc, County Cork. The Commissioners of Public Works are at present considering the suitability of the site which has been offered by the school manager.
It is not possible, at this stage, to say when work on the building of the school will commence.
asked the Minister for Education when he expects that work will commence on the erection of the new boys' national school at Passage West, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Plans have been prepared for a new national school, having accommodation in five classrooms and a general purposes room at Passage West, County Cork; and negotiations with regard to State grant and local contribution towards the cost of the school have been completed. When satisfactory title to the site of the proposed new school has been furnished, the grant will be sanctioned and the further arrangements for the erection of the school will proceed.
asked the Minister for Education the number of (a) one teacher and (b) two teacher and (c) three teacher primary schools which have been brought into larger educational units since 1966.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: During the period from 1966 to 31 December, 1972, the numbers were as follows: (a) one-teacher schools: 560; (b) two-teacher schools: 480; (c) three-teacher schools: 53.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Loughnane Dr. Loughnane Mr. Callanan Mr. Callanan
Speaker.P: and Dr. Loughnane asked the Minister for Education if there is a proposal before his Department to close Kilrickle national school, County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: In view of the opposition expressed by the Kilrickle parents to my Department's proposals for centralisation in Cappatagle of all the schools in the parish, including Kilrickle national school, it is proposed that, for the present, no further action be taken towards the replacement of the Kilrickle school.
asked the Minister for Education the cause of the delay in building the new school at Ruan, County Clare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Following a recent agreement with the school manager regarding the local contribution, my Department has sanctioned a grant towards the cost of the new school at Ruan, County Clare.
The further arrangements for the erection of the school are a matter for the Commissioners of Public Works.
asked the Minister for Education the reason for the delay in approving of the sale of Bennets-church national school, County Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Certain legal and other formalities had to be completed before the agreement of my Department could be given for the sale of the former national school premises at Bennetschurch, County Waterford. I am happy to say that those matters have now been disposed of and that my Department will be communicating with the reverend manager's solicitor without delay as to the payment to be made in respect of the State's interest in the premises.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Athy is one of the areas in which it is proposed to establish a community school. Discussions on this proposal will be resumed shortly with the school authorities concerned.
asked the Minister for Education the number of classrooms and the number of pupils in Scoil Naomh Peadar, Limekiln Road, Walkinstown, County Dublin; and the pupil/teacher ratio in the school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will state (a) the number of pupils from Clare Island and Inisturk and Inisbiggle Islands who have availed of grants to boarding schools for post-primary education since the scheme for island pupils was initiated and (b) the amount paid by his Department by way of grants towards their education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: (a) Twenty-five pupils from Clare Island, Inisturk and Inisbiggle have been awarded boarding grants in post-primary schools since the introduction of the free post-primary education scheme.
(b) The amount paid to date by my Department by way of grant towards their education is £7,377.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kildare Vocational School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will approve the purchase of a site for a new vocational school in Droichead Nua, County Kildare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The County Kildare Vocational Education Committee has already purchased a site for a new vocational school in Droichead Nua but my Department's view is that this site is too far away from the other post-primary schools in the centre. I understand that the committee is negotiating for the purchase of another site. No agreement has been reached in regard to the purchase price of this second site but any such proposal would in any event have to be considered in the context of the future organisation of post-primary education in Droichead Nua. Discussions in the latter regard will be held with all the post-primary school authorities concerned early in the next school year.

Rann na Feirste ar oscailt le haghaidh teagasc a gcuid páistí.
asked the Minister for Education when a decision may be expected on the future of the vocational schools at Ringsend and Upper Mount Street, Dublin.
asked the Minister for Education if he has any plans for replacing the vocational school at Cambridge Road, Ringsend, Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 145 and 146 together.

It has already been agreed that the existing boys' vocational schools in Ringsend and Mount Street be replaced by a new vocational school in Ringsend. The project has been delayed because of site problems. A feasibility study submitted by the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee is at present being examined in the Department. This study proposes that the school should cater for girls as well as boys: this had not been envisaged in the earlier proposals.
I shall have the matter brought to decision with the least possible delay.

asked the Minister for Education if he will confirm that students qualifying at third level from vocational schools will have the same opportunities as students qualifying in the same subjects and at the same level of education from universities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: I am not quite clear as to what the Deputy has in mind. The object of third-level courses in institutions other than the universities is to create a supply of persons with suitable education and training at that level to meet the requirements and demands of our economy. I am confident that employment opportunities will be available to those students who successfully complete third-level courses at such institutions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kilkenny Vocational School Course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether it is intended to provide a senior cycle in Thomastown Vocational School, County Kilkenny.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Yes. With the approval of my Department the County Kilkenny Vocational Education Committee are organising a senior cycle course in Thomastown Vocational School as from next September to cater for the Thomastown/Ballyhale/Graigue-namanagh area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Kilkenny Vocational School Accommodation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of the serious over-crowding and poor accommodation in Kilkenny Vocational School; the steps that are in train to correct this situation; and when students can expect to have proper facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: I received a deputation from the County Kilkenny Vocational Education Committee on this matter recently. It was agreed that revised proposals for additional accommodation and facilities for Kilkenny Vocational School would be submitted to my Department and I undertook to have the proposals examined and a decision arrived at without avoidable delay.
The proposals were received on 20th July and are now being examined.

asked the Minister for Education if biochemistry is included in the curricula of regional technical colleges; and, if so, if it has a separate curriculum or if it is included in the curriculum of some related subject.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Biochemistry is included as a separate subject with its own syllabus in the curriculum of the regional technical colleges. It is also studied as part of the syllabuses of other biological science subjects in these institutions.

asked the Minister for Education how appointments are made to lectureships in regional technical colleges; the degrees or qualifications necessary; and if the Diploma in Higher Education or Ceardteastas is an essential qualification for such appointments.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Appointments to lectureships in regional technical colleges are made on the basis of publicly advertised competitions and of a selection board procedure prescribed by my Department. The qualifications required in each instance are related to the nature of the post and are prescribed in Memorandum V.7 issued by my Department; in general, an honours primary degree and a minimum of three years suitable professional experience are required. A Diploma in Higher Education or the Ceardteastas Gaeilge are not essential qualifications.

asked the Minister for Education if he will establish a research unit at Sligo Regional College to investigate, comment on and advise on the economic, social and environmental problems of Counties Donegal, Sligo, Leitrim, Roscommon and Mayo; and if he will arrange for the provision of management courses in that college to deal specifically with the problems of those areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The activities to be pursued at Sligo Regional Technical College are matters in the first instance for the board of management of that institution, and it would be for the board to establish a research unit of the type mentioned in the Deputy's question, if they thought it necessary or desirable. My function is one of sanction or otherwise for such proposals as the board of management submits to me in relation to the activities of the college.
asked the Minister for Education if he will arrange to have music as a faculty at University College Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: It does not fall within my function to arrange for the establishment of particular faculties within a university institute. Such matters are for consideration by the university authorities in the first instance.

asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that some boarding schools are proposing to opt out of the free education scheme because he will not allow them to increase fees chargeable to parents while the schools continue to avail of Department grants; and if he will make a statement on the position and indicate how many schools have decided to opt out.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The position with regard to fees charged by post-primary boarding schools is that a grant of £30 per annum is made by my Department in respect of each recognised pupil, where the total school fee per pupil is not more than £165 per annum. I may add that my understanding is that increases in school fees are subject to the approval of the National Prices Commission. The question of raising this “ceiling” figure beyond £165 is under consideration, in view of the claims from some schools that the increase in the cost of maintenance demands that a higher fee be charged.
I am not in a position to say at this stage, however, what my decision in that regard may be.
asked the Minister for Education if he has received proposals for the establishment of a field biology centre at the Doneraile estate, County Cork; and, if so, if he will state the present position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The examination of proposals for the establishment of a field biology centre at Doneraile has not yet been completed in my Department. I also understand that a final decision regarding the future use of Doneraile estates and the mansion thereon has not yet been reached.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - College of Art Director.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when it is proposed to appoint a permanent Director to the National College of Art and Design.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The appointment of a permanent Director to the National College of Art and Design is a matter for the board of the college, under the terms of the National College of Art and Design Act, 1971.
I understand that candidates for the post have been interviewed recently.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of graduates who were awarded the Higher Diploma in Education in each year from 1966 to date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The information sought by the Deputy is set out in the form of a tabular statement which, with your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to have circulated with the Official Report.
