MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - An Foclóir Gaeilge-Bhéarla.
MainHeading.P: 159. D'Fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: den Aire Oideachais cén dul chun cinn atá á dhéanamh leis an bhfoclóir Gaeilge-Bhéarla a fhoilsiú.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Rinneadh conradh le clódóirí faoi chló-bhualadh an fhoclóra i mí na Márta seo caite agus tá an chéad chuid den ábhar acu cheana féin. Táthar ag súil go mbeidh an foclóir réidh le cur ar an margadh roimh dheireadh na bliana, 1974.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Remedial School Teachers.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of remedial school teachers in Ireland; the number who are trained each year; and if he is satisfied that the number trained each year is adequate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: There are now approximately 220 full-time remedial teachers serving in national schools.

Up to now the annual output at the special courses for remedial teachers in Orwell Road and at Cork Polio was approximately 50 teachers. This year arrangements are being made to have this number increased by the provision of a further course for 20-25 teachers in St. Patrick's Training College, Drumcondra. I am also investigating the possibility of establishing further courses in other centres.

At post-primary level there are at present 84 recognised teachers engaged in remedial education. The Department has made provision for the training of a further 75 teachers during the school year 1973-74. The Department has been engaged in such in-service training since 1971.

MainHeading.P: I recognise the need for more teachers who have received training in remedial education and as my reply indicates the number of teachers undergoing training in this area is being increased considerably. Whilst a remedial teacher may be regarded as the person, on a school staff, with the main responsibility for remedial education, the remedial problem is, of course, the concern of all the teaching staff.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the provision which is made for slow learning children at primary school level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Two hundred and twenty appointments to full-time posts for remedial teachers have been sanctioned in national schools. In addition, in many schools part-time remedial teaching is carried out by teachers who are free from class duties at certain times during the day.
Saturday morning pilot schemes in remedial teaching are operating in towns, and remedial teaching is also provided in child guidance clinics.

asked the Minister for Education if he will allow the present teacher to continue to teach remedial classes in Edenderry, County Offaly, in view of the fact that the manager is unable to get a fully qualified teacher.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: My Department has not received any notification from the reverend manager of Edenderry boys' national school that he has been unsuccessful in his efforts to obtain a fully qualified and suitable person to undertake remedial teaching in that school.
A teacher engaged in remedial teaching must be qualified to act as a member of the ordinary staff of a school.

I am sorry that, as matters stand, I could not authorise the continued employment by the manager in the school of the teacher to whom the Deputy refers, who is not a fully-qualified teacher in accordance with the rules of my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Kerry School Transport Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the secondary education opportunities available in Ballyvourney, County Cork, for girls living in the Clonkeen district in County Kerry; and whether he will arrange a special suitable public transport service to Killarney for those who choose to attend Killarney secondary schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: A special school transport service operates from Clonkeen to Ballyvourney, which is the nearest post-primary centre. The vocational school in Ballyvourney presents an adequate range of second-level courses for girls all the way to leaving certificate.

Clonkeen pupils who choose to attend schools in Killarney have the facility of free transport on the Kenmare-Killarney public bus service which operates via Poulgorm Bridge. The morning pick-up time at Poulgorm is rather early, but it is not possible to alter it as the bus serves interests other than school children and makes a rail connection at Killarney.

To remedy the situation, I have arranged that for the coming school year the pupils from the Poulgorm and Clonkeen areas will be accommodated on a special school bus which will leave Poulgorm Bridge for Killarney at approximately 8.00 a.m. This will give a substantial improvement all round.
asked the Minister for Education the manner in which applications in respect of free school transport on medical grounds are decided.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Free transport to the nearest suitable school is provided for school children, ineligible under the normal distance regulations, who have serious physical or mental handicaps which would preclude them from walking or cycling to school. Each case is decided on its merits on the basis of the medical evidence submitted.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Bus Owners' Remuneration.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will ensure that the remuneration of school bus owners is adequately increased so as to take account of the steep rise in costs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The remuneration paid to school bus owners is the subject of contractual agreements between CIE and the individual operators concerned. Duration of contracts is usually one year and, on renewal, contractors have an opportunity of negotiating new terms with CIE to compensate for increased costs.
asked the Minister for Education if he will consider making all school books free to children attending secondary and vocational schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: The scheme under which financial aid is provided by my Department for the provision of free books and requisites for post-primary school pupils is intended to meet the requirements of pupils of necessitous families. I am satisfied that the scheme is meeting reasonably well the purpose for which it was designed and I do not propose to expand its scope to the extent of making it applicable to all post-primary pupils.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Community Games Grant.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if, in view of the amount of work being done by the Community Games Committee and the importance of the success of these games, he will consider the allocation of a further grant to them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: Grant-aided organisations, including the National Community Games, have been requested to submit applications for assistance in respect of their 1974-75 activities before 31st December, 1973. When the application of the National Community Games is received, it will be sympathetically considered.
asked the Minister for Education if he will review the National Sports Council with a view to strengthening it.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) Richard (Dick) Burke
Speaker.P: This matter is at present under review.

asked the Minister for Justice if he will indicate in detail the changes, if any, made in the composition and/or the terms of reference of any State board, commission or committee under the aegis of his Department since 14th March, 1973.
asked the Minister for Justice if any new board, commission or committee has been established under the aegis of his Department since 14th March, 1973; and, if so, if he will give details.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: I propose with your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, to take Questions Nos. 169 and 170 together.

Since 14th March, 1973, there have been no changes in the composition and/or the terms of reference of any State board, commission or committee under the aegis of my Department nor has any new board, commission or committee been established.

asked the Minister for Justice whether he will make available to the family of the late Patrick Leonard, Pettigo, County Donegal, copies of all statements relating to his death now in the hands of the Garda.

asked the Minister for Justice whether he is aware that the Garda in Pettigo took statements from several people in connection with the Leonard shooting which took place near Beleek on the 17th May; and if he will state the purpose of this and the action he intends taking about this incident.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle I propose to take Questions Nos. 171 and 172 together.

The statements were taken in the course of routine Garda inquiries. It would not be in accordance with normal practice for the Garda to furnish copies of the statements to members of the public. There is no action open to me in relation to this tragic death. I would refer the Deputy to the reply given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs today to other questions on the same subject.
asked the Minister for Justice whether a decision has been taken or is in contemplation to release all prisoners held following conviction under the Offences Against the State Acts.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: The answer to both parts of the question is “No”.
asked the Minister for Justice whether prisoners convicted under the Offences Against the State Acts in all places of detention are treated equally; and, if not, why.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: There are minor differences in conditions as between one place and another which are unavoidable because of the accommodation available in and the custodial requirements of these places but otherwise all prisoners are treated equally.

asked the Minister for Justice the amount which is being made available during this financial year for the provision of education, rehabilitation and welfare services for prisoners; the percentage this is of the total expenditure on prisoners; and the personnel that are engaged in these services.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am afraid that it would not be possible to break down the expenditure on the prison service in the manner requested. The cost of new accommodation or staff salaries or of provisions, for example, could not be attributed wholly to the custodial as distinct from the rehabilitative function of the service and neither could the function of the prison officer be reckoned as custodial only.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Offences Against the State Act.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice whether the repeal of (1) the Offences Against the State Acts, 1939 and 1940 or (2) the Offences Against the State (Amendment) Act, 1972, is under consideration by the Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: The answer is “No”.

asked the Minister for Justice if his attention has been drawn to a recent document on prison conditions in Europe; if he intends to take steps to have its provisions implemented in Ireland; if not, why; and, if so, when.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: I assume the Deputy is referring to a resolution embodying what are called Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, which was adopted by the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe in January, 1973. These rules are not binding on the Member States but, as stated in the rules, they set out what is generally accepted as being good principle and practice in the treatment of prisoners and the management of institutions.

I am glad to be able to inform the Deputy that, in general, the treatment of prisoners in this country is in full accord with the principles embodied in the rules and in some respects is more favourable than is specified in the rules.
We are not yet in a position to give full effect to a few of the rules but the work currently in hands on accommodation and methods of treatment will enable us progressively to do so.
asked the Minister for Justice the number of cases of bigamy that have been before the courts in the past ten years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: The particulars sought by the Deputy are furnished in the annual reports of the Commissioner of the Garda Síochána on crime, copies of which are available in the Oireachtas Library.
The Commissioner's report for 1972 will be published shortly but I understand that there were no cases of bigamy reported or known to the Garda during that year.
The total number of such cases reported or known to the Garda during the ten years ended on 30th September, 1972, was ten.

asked the Minister for Justice the cause of the delay in the Land Registry in connection with an application (details supplied) made by Offaly County Council for title to the council's private building sites at Edenderry, County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: Registration of the holdings referred to was completed early in 1971.

An application was made on 19th February, 1973, for first registration of a small plot of land and for consolidation with these holdings. A query in the matter was issued by the Registrar of Titles and Deeds on 30th April, 1973. This query has not yet been discharged.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Gaming and Lotteries Act.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if it is proposed to introduce legislation to amend the Gaming and Lotteries Act, 1956.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: Many areas of the law will be receiving my attention and I have no doubt that the subject mentioned by the Deputy will come up for review in due course. If I have any proposals in the matter, I will bring them before the House.
asked the Minister for Justice the specific duties which are allotted to members of the BanGhardaí in the Dublin city area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: Ban-Ghardaí perform general police duties. They are, however, assigned mainly to duties for which they are particularly suited. These include acting as juvenile liaison officers, dealing with drug abuse and with offences involving women and children.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Donegal Garda Strength.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the demand by the following towns for extra Gardaí: Moville, Muff, Culdaff, Buncrana, Cloonmany, County Donegal; and if he will indicate the proposals he has to facilitate them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Commissioner that Garda strength at the stations mentioned is reasonably adequate for the current police needs of the areas. There are no proposals at present to increase strength at these stations but the matter is being kept under review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Burke Mr. L. Burke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of Gardaí who were precluded under the Garda promotion regulations from attending promotion interviews by reason of their failure to pass the prescribed examination in oral Irish; and if, in view of the recent easement in regard to Irish in the intermediate and leaving certificate examinations, he will consider amending the Garda promotion regulations to enable unsuccessful candidates to compete at future promotion interviews.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: It has not been possible in the time available to carry out an exhaustive examination of the relevant Garda records but the Commissioner informs me that, as far as can be readily ascertained, only one Garda is precluded from attending an interview for promotion by reason of failing the oral Irish test.

I do not think that the question of a knowledge of the Irish language for promotion purposes in the Garda Síochána should be separated from the broader issue of the Irish language requirement in the public service generally on which the Minister for Finance made a statement in the House on the 20th June last.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cork City Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Burke Mr. L. Burke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if it is his intention to provide a new Garda station in the Mayfield/Tivoli area of Cork city; and if the section of this area which is at present under the jurisdiction of the Glanmire Garda station will come under the city division.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: The question of providing a Garda station in the Mayfield/Tivoli area is being examined as part of a general review of the police needs of Cork city and surrounding areas. Pending completion of this review and receipt of the Garda Commissioner's recommendations, I am not in a position to say what the outcome will be.

asked the Minister for Health if he will make a statement on the progress to date towards integrating the Departments of Health and Social Welfare; and when it is envisaged that complete integration will have been achieved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I assume that the Deputy is referring to the amalgamation of the two Departments on the lines recommended by the Public Services Organisation Review Group. No decision has yet been taken as to whether or not the two Departments will be amalgamated.

In the interim, practical co-ordination of the activities of my two Departments exists where the needs of particular services call for it. It is my intention to improve this where it is found necessary.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Western Health Board Development Plan.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when sanction will be issued to the Western Health Board for the development plan submitted by them for Castlebar Hospital, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The Western Health Board's five year development plan for the County Hospital at Castlebar, County Mayo is under examination in my Department but it will take some further time before decisions in detail in relation to it can be arrived at. Several of the proposals in the plan have, however, already been accepted in principle by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Western Health Board Psychiatric Unit.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has received any proposals for the erection of a psychiatric unit at Ballina, County Mayo for the Western Health Board.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I have received such proposals and they are being considered in the context of other proposals and developments relating to the improvement of the psychiatric services in the western counties. I cannot at this stage indicate the likely outcome.

asked the Minister for Health if he will amend the law whereby committed alcoholics can be released from mental homes if the resident medical officers so decide without reference to the person who made the commitment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: Under existing statutory provisions, when a person, including an alcoholic, detained as a private patient is fit for discharge from a mental hospital the person paying for his hospital care must be informed. Where other detained patients are concerned, the person in charge of the hospital must inform a relative. In both instances the patient, if not removed within seven days, will, in any event, be discharged.

I would not be prepared to amend the law so as to provide that discharge could only be with the consent of a relative or other person. I assume that this is what the Deputy has in mind. I would like to emphasise that the existing arrangements have been devised to safeguard the freedom of the individual.
asked the Minister for Health if he has sanctioned the appointment of a doctor to Ballina Hospital, County Mayo; and, if so, the salary for the post.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy has in mind the post of permanent medical Officer to Ballina Hospital. An appointment of this kind is made by the chief executive officer of the Health board on the recommendation of the Local Appointments Commission and my sanction is not necessary. I am informed that the Local Appointments Commission have been requested by the health board to hold a competition for the filling of the Ballina permanent post. The post is part-time and the salary for it is £2,809 per annum.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mayo Hospital Radiologist.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when he will sanction the appointment of a second radiologist for the County Hospital, Castlebar, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I have no proposal for the appointment of a second radiologist for the County Hospital, Castlebar.

MainHeading.P: I am informed that proposals for improving the radiology services in their area have been submitted by the Western Health Board to Comhairle na nOspidéal, the statutory body set up under the Health Act, 1970 to regulate the number and type of appointments of consultant medical staffs in hospitals providing services under the Act. These proposals, which are under active consideration by the comhairle, involve the creation of a second post of radiologist to serve in County Mayo.
I shall give immediate consideration to any proposals which may be made to me following the examination now being carried out by the Comhairle.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the total amount collected under the Health Contributions Act since its inception; and the corresponding amount expended on hospitalisation in the same period.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The scheme of health contributions came into operation on 1st October, 1971. The total amount collected during the first 18 months, i.e., up to 31st March, 1973, was £6,675,036. The amount which it is estimated will be collected in 1973-74 is £5 million.

It is assumed that the Deputy has in mind the revenue cost of hospital services. The estimated current expenditure on health board and voluntary hospital services, including homes for the mentally handicapped and the aged, in the financial years mentioned is as follows: 1971-72, £63 million; 1972-73, £77 million; 1973-74 £90 million.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Physiotherapy Treatment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has any proposals to enable a patient in the middle income group to continue physiotherapy treatment free of charge on discharge from hospital.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: Patients in the middle income group who require continuing physiotherapy treatment on discharge from hospital are entitled to such treatment free of charge if provided at or by persons attached to a hospital or home or similar premises, e.g. clinic, health centre, of the health board or of a voluntary institution with which the health board has made appropriate arrangements.

MainHeading.P: If the Deputy has any specific cases of difficulty in mind, I shall have them investigated if he supplies particulars.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if, in view of the concern in Roscommon town and district with regard to the future of Roscommon County Hospital, he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my comprehensive reply of 28th March to Parliamentary questions about the hospital development programme.

The situation in summary is that until the new administrative bodies in the health field have reviewed how the basic considerations in the Fitzgerald Report might be applied in detail in particular areas, it would be premature to make any statement about an individual hospital.
asked the Minister for Health if it is intended to build a hospital in the new town of Tallaght, County Dublin; and, if so, when it will be commenced.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my comprehensive reply of 28th March about the hospital development programme.

The situation in summary is that until the new administrative bodies in the health field have reviewed how the basic considerations in the Fitzgerald Report might be applied in detail it would be premature to reach a decision as to the provision of a new hospital for a particular area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Wicklow Medical Card Applicant.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the reason for the delay in providing a medical card for a person (name supplied) in County Wicklow who made an application to the Eastern Health Board some time ago.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The granting or refusal of a medical card is a statutory function of the chief executive officer of a health board. I understand that there was no unreasonable delay in dealing with the case referred to by the Deputy.

asked the Minister for Health if it is intended to set up a series of community social service centres, in close association with health and social services boards, to implement the personal social services on a family-oriented basis and to link statutory and voluntary bodies to meet social needs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I have indicated already that I regard the provision of social service centres and the unifying of voluntary and statutory effort in the community care field as key areas for action.

The Deputy will appreciate that such action necessarily involves considerable consultation and discussion between statutory and voluntary agencies. It has been made clear to health boards that I wish to see maximum co-operation between them and the voluntary bodies who are meeting social needs.

The position regarding the setting up of local social service councils, which are designed to co-ordinate statutory and voluntary effort in the provision of various services, is satisfactory. To date, more than 50 such councils have been formed throughout the country and more are in process of formation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Assistance Butter Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will extend the EEC social assistance butter scheme so that persons in receipt of disablement and tuberculosis allowances from health boards will benefit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I presume that the Deputy is referring to persons in receipt of either a disabled persons (maintenance) allowance or an infectious diseases (maintenance) allowance, payable by health boards under the Health Acts. If so, the position is that the EEC social assistance butter scheme already applies to such persons.
asked the Minister for Health the number of specialists in geriatrics who are working for the various health boards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The number is four. One of them is employed direct by a health board; the other three are employed by the authorities of two general hospitals with which the health board for the area concerned has made arrangements for the provision of services.
Four other health boards are in the process of filling posts in their areas.

Proposals for the creation of such posts have now to be submitted to Comhairle na nOspidéal, the statutory body set up under the Health Act, 1970, to regulate the number and type to appointments of consultant medical staff in hospitals providing services under the Act.
asked the Minister for Health the total number of district nurses employed by health boards; and if he considers that this number is adequate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: There are 781 public health nurses in the health board's service.

A survey of the public health nursing services has been concluded and the information derived from it is being processed. When this has been completed, I shall be better able to assess the adequacy of the numbers currently employed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Meath Medical Card Holders.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the number of medical card holders in County Meath with valuation under £20, under £25, under £30, under £35, under £40 and over £40.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: This information is not available in my Department and I understand that it is not readily available in the North-Eastern Health Board offices.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hospital Admission Waiting Lists.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the number of patients in each health board area who were on waiting lists for admission to hospital for treatment in each of the following departments at some recent date: (a) surgical (b) medical (c) gynaecological (d) paediatric (e) ophthalmic (f) ENT (g) orthopaedic (h) urological and (i) dermatological.

asked the Minister for Health the number of people in each health board area awaiting calls to each of the following out-patients clinics: (a) surgical (b) medical (c) gynaecological (d) paediatric (e) ophthalmic (f) ENT (g) orthopaedic (h) urological and (i) dermatological.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 201 and 202 together.

I recently replied to a number of questions about waiting lists for admission to hospital and about delays at hospital out-patient clinics. Those questions related to particular specialities or particular areas. I would refer the Deputy to my replies of 2nd May to Deputy Lemass about cataract operations, and of 17th July to questions by Deputy O'Connell about hospital out-patient and x-ray services, and about squint operations.

The position broadly, with which my Department is familiar from close contact with hospitals, is that we have no problem of unduly long waiting periods either as respects in-patient or out-patient general hospital care and, in that situation, the interest of my Department has been in relation to pressing problems regarding particular specialties when they arise.

For this reason the detailed breakdown of information which the Deputy seeks is not at present available and I believe the Labour involved in compiling such a detailed breakdown covering so many aspects of out-patient and in-patient services would not be justified.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EEC Social Security Regulations.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the social services for dependants of persons resident in Britain or for British pensioners resident here for which this country will be recouped by the British Government under EEC regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The reference by the Minister for Finance in his financial statement on the 1973 budget on the 16th May last, Official Report, Volume 265, No. 9, column 1244, lines 18-23, to which the Deputy's question relates is to an advance of £1.5 million in respect of the current financial year to be made to this country arising from the operation of EEC Regulation No. 1408/71. This governs the provision of social security for migrant workers. The advance is in respect of health services and is included as an appropriation-in-aid to the Vote for Health.

This regulation preserves for migrant workers and for social security pensioners and their dependants their earned entitlement to social security benefits, including health services, when in any of the member States of the EEC. The advance of £1.5 million is in respect of the estimated imbalance in the financial year 1973-74 as between the cost of providing health services for eligible persons in Ireland for whom the United Kingdom is liable and vice versa.
asked the Minister for Health the action his Department intends to take regarding the implementation of the Heering Report requisitioned by the National Rehabilitation Board.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I am having the Heering Report and the National Rehabilitations Board's observations thereon examined along with the whole field of activity in the rehabilitation services. The Heering recommendations and the observations of the board cover both vocational training and sheltered employment, and the developments envisaged would result over a period of years in significant additional expenditure. When the examination of the proposals is complete, I propose to communicate to the National Rehabilitation Board and, where appropriate, to health boards the improved arrangements in these areas which I consider necessary.

asked the Minister for Health if he will consider applications from the National Rehabilitation Board for grants to voluntary bodies dealing with mentally and physically handicapped persons, in view of the fact that these bodies are doing excellent work but that their efforts are being hampered because of lack of funds.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: Within the limits of the capital programme of my Department and having regard to priorities in other fields for which I am responsible, I am prepared to consider assistance by way of grant towards capital projects of established voluntary organisations in the areas referred to by the Deputy. In the normal course the advice of the National Rehabilitation Board is sought on such projects. I may say that I have recently approved of two such grants.
asked the Minister for Health when it is proposed to provide an ambulance service for Achill, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The Western Health Board are at present considering locating an ambulance in Achill and hope to arrive at a decision soon with regard to this proposal.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare why allowances to the children of widows do not extend to the 31st July of the academic year in which their schooling ends.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: An allowance as part of her pension is payable to a widow in respect of a qualified child who is between the age of 18 and 21 years provided that he is receiving full-time instruction by day at any university, college, school or other educational establishment. There is no provision in the Social Welfare Acts which would enable payment of the allowance to be continued for any period after the date on which the child ceases to receive such full-time instruction.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Old Age Care Allowances.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the number of people in receipt of old age care allowances.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The number of people in receipt of old age care allowance is 24.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Timmons Mr. Timmons Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass Mr. Gogan Mr. Gogan
Speaker.P: and Mr. Timmons asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will ensure that recipients of home assistance will not receive a cut in their allowances as a result of the increases granted in social welfare in the budget.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: Public assistance authorities are required by statute to pay home assistance in appropriate cases. It is for each authority to determine the degree of need and the proper amount of assistance payable. While I, as Minister for Social Welfare, have responsibility for the general direction and control of the scheme of home assistance, I am expressly precluded from directing the giving of public assistance to any individual person.

From inquiries which have been made by my Department, it appears to be the position that home assistance allowances are not being reduced by the public assistance authorities because of the budget increases in social welfare payments. If, however, the Deputies are in possession of information to the contrary and supply me with particulars, I will certainly have the matter taken up with the authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Meath Disability Benefit Claims.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for the delay in dealing with the claim of a person (name supplied) in Long-wood, County Meath who has received no disability benefit although he has submitted certificates since 14th March, 1973.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: There is confusion of insurance numbers between the person referred to by the Deputy in his question and two other persons of the same name. Although the matter has not yet been fully resolved, investigations to date have revealed that the person referred to by the Deputy had sufficient insurable employment to qualify him for disability benefit. All benefit due was accordingly paid.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for the delay in dealing with the disability benefit claim of a person (name supplied) in Summerhill, County Meath; and when benefit will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The person referred to by the Deputy in his question submitted only one medical certificate, a hospital certificate showing that he was incapable of work on a specified day. In the absence of further medical evidence estabilishing a period of continuing incapacity for work no benefit could be paid. As he resumed work without furnishing a final medical certificate he has been asked to forward a statement from his employer giving the inclusive dates of his absence from work through illness. When this statement is received any benefit to which he may be entitled will be paid.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for the delay in payment of disability benefit to a person (name supplied) in Trim, County Meath; and when payment will be made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The person referred to by the Deputy in his question was not initially qualified for payment of disability benefit as his 1972 insurance card had not been received in the Department. The card has since been obtained and all benefit due has been issued to him.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare why an applicant (name supplied) in County Kerry was not paid unemployment benefit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The claim for unemployment benefit by the person in question was disallowed by a decision of a deciding officer on the grounds that he lost his employment by reason of a stoppage of work which was due to a trade dispute at his place of employment. The decision of the deciding officer was upheld by an appeals officer.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will increase by 50p the amount allowed to unemployed applicants under paragraph (b) (ii) (A) of Article 7 of S.I. No. 7 of 1953.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The statutory regulations in question are at present being reviewed with particular reference to the adequacy of the existing limit of 50p a day on remuneration from a subsidiary occupation.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare how remuneration or profit is estimated for the operation of paragraph (b) (ii) (A) of Article 7 of S.I. No. 7 of 1953 in the case of (a) farmers, (b) non-farmers and (c) females; and if land valuation or the stock of crops are the criteria accepted.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: No distinction is made in the regulations in question between claimants to unemployment benefit on an occupational or sex basis. Remuneration or profit in the case of any particular claimant is assessed on a factual basis, allowance being made for any expenses that are necessarily incurred in the course of the subsidiary occupation. The rateable valuation of land, therefore, is not taken as a criterion for farm income in this connection.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare if it is a fact that a recipient of an English contributory old age pension of £7 per week qualifies for an Irish non-contributory old age pension of up to £3 per week, while the recipient of an Irish contributory old age pension of a similar amount does not qualify for any non-contributory old age pension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: When the old age, contributory, pension scheme, which is based on a person's insurance record without regard to means, was introduced in this country in January, 1961, it was provided that receipt of the contributory pension would be a disqualification for entitlement to a non-contributory old age pension. We are, therefore, precluded from paying a contributory and a non-contributory pension concurrently to the same person. However, a British retirement pension payable to a person permanently resident in this State is simply taken into account as means for old age non-contributory pension purposes and, accordingly, it is a fact that, subject to fulfilment of the other statutory conditions, the situation described by the Deputy could arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he is aware of continued complaints by old age pensioners about the need to produce pension books to avail of free public travel and the dangers of loss and theft of books arising from this system; and if he will introduce the public travel card system for such persons.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The present method of issuing travel passes to pensioners by means of slips attached to their pension order books has worked satisfactorily since the inception of the scheme and there has been no significant number of complaints. However, arrangements for the issue of separate passes to holders of pension books are nearing finality and it is hoped to commence issuing such passes in the near future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will arrange to have deleted from the outside of the postal envelope covers the D.W. reference for persons in receipt of the deserted wife's allowance.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I am arranging that the letters referred to by the Deputy will not be used in future on envelope covers addressed to recipients of deserted wife's allowance.
asked the Minister for Social Welfare the number of sociologists employed in his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: There is no sociologist employed as such in my Department at present.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Army Gratuities.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence the basis on which army gratuities are paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: Under the Defence Forces (Pensions) Schemes, a married officer retiring after 12 or more years' service is eligible for a gratuity in addition to retired pay. This gratuity is not payrelated but is based on rank and length of service. However, a married officer retiring within four years of the age limit for his rank receives an enhanced gratuity. The maximum gratuity which is equal to one and one-half years' pay is payable if retirement takes place within two years of the age limit.

MainHeading.P: A married non-commissioned officer or private discharged on pension is eligible for a gratuity of one week's pay, including additional pay if any, for each year of service subject to a maximum of 31 weeks' pay.
Officers and soliders who are not eligible for retired pay or pension because they have not the requisite service are eligible for gratuities at the rates laid down in the schemes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence the net increase in army strength since the 1st March, 1973.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: The strength of the Army on 30th June, 1973, was 67 less than on 28th February, 1973.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Reserve Defence Forces Promotion.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if he is aware of the need to review the reserve defence forces, as distinct from the FCA, in the context of promotion from captain to commandant and upwards; and if he will consider integrating the first line reserve with the FCA.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: Some years ago Defence Force regulations were amended so as to provide that all lieutenants of the Reserve of Officers (First Line) would be eligible for promotion to the rank of captain. In view of the organisation and requirements of this class of the Reserve, I do not consider that there is any need to review the position in the context of promotion beyond the rank of captain. The answer to the second half of the question is “No”.

asked the Minister for Defence why two stokers were dismissed from the corps of engineers, Curragh Camp on 1st June last and on the following Monday morning three new men were employed as general labourers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: Six men nominated by the local employment exchange were taken on by the Corps of Engineers at the Curragh Training Camp as temporary stokers for the heating season from September, 1972, to May, 1973. It was made clear to them when they were employed that the work was of a seasonal nature only. In mid-May, 1973, the employees were given advance notice in writing that the heating season was due to end and that, when it did, they would become redundant. The heating season ended on 30th May, 1973, and I regret that it was necessary to terminate their services on 1st June, 1973.

My Department is unable to trace a record of any appointment as general labourer, or in any other capacity as labourer, on Monday, 4th June, 1973. If the Deputy would give additional particulars regarding the alleged employments, I will have the matter further investigated.
asked the Minister for Defence whether he is satisfied with conditions obtaining for prisoners in the Curragh detention camp.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: Apart from the fact that the barracks were not designed as a custodial prison, I am generally satisfied with the conditions.
asked the Minister for Defence whether he is satisfied with the facilities afforded visitors to the Curragh detention camp.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: The answer is “Yes”.
asked the Minister for Local Government if he will circulate the revision of constituencies Bill before the summer recess.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: I do not propose to circulate the Electoral (Amendment) (No. 2) Bill, 1973, before the summer recess.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Local Authority House Heating.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the percentage of local authority houses under construction or planned which will have central heating.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: Because housing authorities themselves now have responsibility for the planning and execution of most local authority housing schemes, the information is not available in my Department in the form requested by the Deputy. Central heating is being provided in almost 86 per cent of housing schemes being built for local authorities by the National Building Agency. It is my policy, generally, to encourage the provision of modern heating facilities in local authority housing schemes. It is a matter for each authority, in the first instance, to decide whether central heating is suitable for a particular scheme.

asked the Minister for Local Government if he will state (1) the number of local authority houses built in each of the last three years in County Wexford and (2) the number of houses which it is proposed to build this year and their location in the county.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: The numbers of local authority houses completed in County Wexford in the financial years 1970-71, 1971-72 and 1972-73 were 93, 190 and 38 respectively. Thirty-eight houses were completed in the first quarter of the current financial year—16 in Duncannon; 12 in Fethard; six in Kilmore village and four rural cottages. At the 30th June, 1973, 322 houses were under construction and there were 393 houses in schemes at tender stage. As the planning and execution of almost all of these schemes is now a matter for the housing authorities, I am not in a position to give the total number of houses which will be completed in the county this year or details of the number of houses in individual schemes which will be completed this year. No doubt if the Deputy gets in touch with the housing authorities concerned they will be able to supply him with more detailed information.
asked the Minister for Local Government if he has any plans for the building of extra houses at Horkan's Hill, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: This site was planned originally for 48 houses, 36 of which have been built so far. The building of the balance of the houses on the higher part of the site was deferred because of an adverse report on site conditions. Last week I received a copy of a resolution from the urban district council seeking sanction immediately to the building of the balance of 12 houses and I understand that a documented proposal is being submitted in this connection on behalf of the council. I will have the matter examined without delay by my Department's technical advisers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Monaghan Reconstruction Grant.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the reason for delay in dealing with a reconstruction grant for a person (name supplied) in County Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: A reconstruction grant of £200 was allocated on 20th February, 1973. The work has been satisfactorily completed and payment will be made shortly.

I regret there has been some delay in dealing with this case due to the growth in the number of applications in the past year and a shortage of inspectors. Arrangements are being made to recruit additional inspectors.
asked the Minister for Local Government the number of compulsory purchase orders submitted by Dublin Corporation which are awaiting decision; and the areas to which the orders refer.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: Eleven. The areas to which the orders refer are: (1) Finglas South-Tolka Valley Area; (2) Tallagt-Whitestown-Jobstown Area; (3) Ballycragh-Oldcourt Area; (4) Glasanaon Road Area; (5) Sherrard Street-Portland Place Area; (6) Charlemont Street-Charlemont Place Area; (7) Camden Street Lower-Harcourt Street Area; (8) Ballymun Road (Griffith Avenue to Ballymun Avenue) Area; (9) Sandford Road Area; (10) Kilmore Road (Skelly's Lane-to-Malahide Road) Area; (11) Westland Row/Pearse Street Area.
asked the Minister for Local Government if he intends to take action against any building society or mortgage broker who makes it a condition that loan applicants take out insurance policies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: As I stated in my reply to Parliamentary question No. 26 of the 19th June last, I have asked the building societies to consider drawing up an agreed code of practice governing their activities. Requirements involving the taking out of insurance by borrowers are matters which I would visualise as falling within the scope of the code of practice.
asked the Minister for Local Government the amount of deposits in the building societies on 30th June 1973 and on 30th June 1972.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: Figures published by the Central Bank in its quarterly bulletin for spring, 1973 show that the aggregate value of shares and deposits with building societies at the 30th June, 1972, amounted to £121.9 million approximately, of which deposits accounted for £20.5 million.
The corresponding figure for 31st March, 1973, the latest date for which figures have been published was £147 million, of which deposits accounted for £23.5 million.

asked the Minister for Local Government the total amount borrowed from the building societies for house purchase during the financial year ended 31st March 1973 and during the first three months of the current financial year; the number of loan applications received by each building society during the same periods; and the number of applications granted and the number refused.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: Building societies advanced £43,214,000 in house purchase loans and approved 12,335 loans for this purpose during the financial year ended 31st March, 1973. Corresponding information for the first three months of the current financial year is not yet available but will be published in the next edition of the Quarterly Bulletin of Housing Statistics. I will arrange to have a copy of the bulletin forwarded to the Deputy in due course.
Details of numbers of loan applications received or refused by building societies are not submitted to my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the effect of the building societies' decisions on the 1973-74 housing target figure of the Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: As I indicated in my reply to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 7 and 8 of the 19th July, I am keeping the situation in relation to the availability of loans from building societies under close review and I am very hopeful that the Government's housing target for the current financial year will be achieved.

asked the Minister for Local Government the total amount borrowed from the three local authorities in the Dublin area for house purchase during the financial year ended 31st March 1973 and during the first three months of the present financial year; the number of loan applications received by each Local authority during the same periods; and the number of applications granted and the number refused.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: During the year ended on the 31st March, 1973, the three local authorities in the Dublin area, Dublin County Council, Dublin Corporation and Dún Laoghaire Borough Corporation, advanced a total of £2,708,324 in house purchase loans. In the same period, the authorities received 1,317 and approved 1,095 loan applications.

In the first three months of the current financial year, the three authorities advanced a total of £869,643 in loans and received 585 and approved 417 applications. Information on the number of applications refused is not available in my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Housing Loans and Grants.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government if he proposes to increase the amount allowed for each dependant in calculating eligibility for local authority loans and supplementary new house grants.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: There is an allowance for dependants in assessing income eligibility for new house supplementary grants, but not in determining income eligibility for local authority loans.

I increased the income limits for loans and supplementary grants on 25th May last. These limits are being kept under review and the question of increasing the allowances for dependants will be considered by me when the next revision is being made.

asked the Minister for Local Government the estimated cost (a) in the current financial year and (b) in a full year of each of the changes in the differential rents system recently announced by him; and the reasons for these changes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: The new national differential rent scheme which is being applied uniformly throughout the country with effect from 1st July, 1973, is estimated to cost an additional £1.5 million in the current year and £2 million in a full year. The new scheme was introduced to remove the unjust aspects of differential rents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass Mr. Timmons Mr. Timmons
Speaker.P: and Mr. Lemass asked the Minister for Local Government the steps he proposes to take following the increase by local authorities of the rents of old age pensioners and of tenants who are in receipt of the increased social welfare benefits granted in the budget.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: As Deputies are aware, I recently announced a new national differential rent scheme which is being applied uniformly throughout the country with effect from 1st July, 1973. The new scheme is particularly beneficial to tenants who are solely dependent on social welfare benefits. For example, a tenant in the Dublin Corporation area whose sole income is the contributory old age pension of £7.20 and who would have been due to pay £1.03 in rent under an old scheme will be required to pay only 10p in rent under the new national scheme.
asked the Minister for Local Government when he will give sanction to the new purchase scheme for tenants of local authority houses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: New purchase terms for existing local authority houses were announced by me this morning.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Water and Sewerage Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the reason for the delay in commencing work on the Aherla/Kilcrea group water scheme, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: I understand that the group have not, as yet, obtained a tender for the carrying out of the work. When this is received in my Department, firm costings will be determined and the appropriate grants will be allocated so that work may commence.
asked the Minister for Local Government if contracts have been placed for the carrying out of the mid-Kerry regional water scheme; and, if so, when work can be expected to start.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Regional Development Aid.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the most severe problem that will entitle an area to regional development aid under EEC regional policy and which may be adopted as a second principle for entitlement to such aid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: Since the Community has not adopted criteria for establishing the areas in which development measures may be assisted by the proposed Regional Development Fund, it is not possible at this stage to give a definitive answer to the Deputy's question.

MainHeading.P: The final communique of the Paris Summit contemplated that intervention by a Regional Development Fund in conjunction with national aids should permit, progressively with the realisation of economic and monetary union, the correction of the main regional imbalances in the enlarged Community, and particularly those resulting from the preponderance of agriculture, from industrial change and from structural under-employment. The Summit did not, however, determine or contemplate that these latter or other problems would be ranked in order of priority in the way apparently implied by the Deputy's question. The approach of the Summit is reflected in the report of the Commission on the regional problems of the enlarged Community. This report sets out the Commission's general views on the considerations which should guide the identification of the areas which should be eligible to benefit from the interventions of the Regional Development Fund. The relevant extract from the report is given in pages 75-76 of the First Report on Development in the European Communities, to which I would refer the Deputy.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the policies and provisions relating to regional development which the Government considers the programme for the second stage of economic and monetary union must include to help to close the gap between this country's standard of living and that of the EEC.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: The evolution of Community regional policy, although related to economic and monetary union, should be looked at as separate and distinct from progress towards that union, as was emphasised in a reply on 28th June to a question from the Deputy. The principles which should, in the Government's view, be observed in the development of Community regional policy are set out in the section on regional policy of my financial statement on the budget, to which I would refer the Deputy. Those which are particularly relevant in the context of the Deputy's question are that the proposed regional development fund must be financed on a scale commensurate with the great tasks it will face, and that its resources must be concentrated on areas where the most severe problems exist.

asked the Minister for Finance the internal measures taken and those which will be taken by his Department to ensure that Ireland will be ready to take full advantage of the opportunities which the EEC regional policy will offer.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: Since it is not yet clear what precise form Community regional policy will take, following decisions on the proposals for the development of that policy which the Commission was invited to put forward by the Paris Summit, it is not possible at this stage to decide what measures will be necessary to draw maximum benefit from that policy. The Deputy may rest assured, however, that the Government are keeping in very close touch with developments, and that any necessary measures will be taken immediately the opportunity arises.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the most recent figures for external trading; and if he will make a statement on the present trend.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: In June last, merchandise imports amounted to £89.8 million and merchandise exports to £70.9 million. As compared with June, 1972, imports were £21.2 million or 30.9 per cent higher and exports £14.8 million or 26.4 per cent higher.

In the first half of 1973 imports totalled £540.4 million and exports £393.2 million. These figures represent increases of 34.8 per cent and 35.4 per cent respectively over those for the first half of 1972.

The trends disclosed by the recent trade returns are not a cause for concern. The buoyancy of exports to which both agricultural and industrial products have contributed is particularly gratifying. On the other hand, much of the increase in imports is attributable to larger purchases of raw materials and capital goods which are necessary to sustain the high level of economic activity. As an increase in net receipts from invisible items is anticipated I expect that the deficit in the balance of payments for the year as a whole, while likely to be greater than last year, will not be such as to cause concern.
asked the Minister for Finance whether he will make a statement on the reports that Ireland leads the price-rise race.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy's question refers to newspaper comment on certain data contained in the July, 1973, publication of the OECD Economic Outlook. Some newspapers erroneously reported the OECD as stating that prices here rose by 18 per cent between mid-November and mid-February, whereas the figure quoted in the review was simply the actual increase that took place, 4.0 per cent, which if converted to an annual rate would mean an 18 per cent annual rise. The OECD figure being based on data for the three months to mid-February does not reflect current trends. More up-to-date data, converted along OECD lines, would, in fact, show a halving of the rate of inflation in the three months ending mid-May.

Even allowing for these qualifications however, it remains true that the OECD figures do show a higher rate of inflation here for the period concerned than in other member countries of the organisation. To the extent that the comparison indicates a loss of international competitiveness of goods and services produced here, it emphasises the need for firm action to keep domestic costs under control. On the prices front, the House is aware of the far-reaching measures put into effect by the Government. In the area of production costs, a crucial factor is the terms of settlement of pay-increases reached when the present national agreement expires. Responsible decisions by the social partners in this sphere can make a large contribution to moderating the pace of inflation here, enhancing competitiveness, and promoting growth and employment.

Speaker.P: It is hoped that the extended school will be ready for occupation in September next.
asked the Minister for Finance the present position regarding the provision of a new national school at Coolavin, Monasteraden, County Sligo; and why work on this school has not started already.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: The response to the invitation of tenders for the erection of this school was unsatisfactory. Tenders have been reinvited and are due on 22nd August, 1973.
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will consider giving a subsidy to county committees of agriculture for the eradication of foxes on a national scale.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: Schemes for destruction of foxes are operated with the approval of my Department by most of the county committees of agriculture. I am prepared to continue support to county committees who operate such schemes on the basis that the committee in each case should settle the terms of the scheme to suit local requirements.
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he has any plans to build a pier at Bullsmouth, Achill, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: The Office of Public Works have been asked by my Department to furnish an engineering report and estimate of costs of providing a pier at Purteen, Bullsmouth, Achill, County Mayo. Until that report is received and examined I cannot say what the outcome may be.
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries when he proposes to build a pier at Frenchport, Belmullet, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: If the Mayo County Council agree to provide an approach road to the site at Frenchport which is favoured by the local fishermen as a landing place, I will be prepared to seek approval for a grant towards the cost of providing suitable landing facilities there.
asked the Minister for Labour the proposals AnCo have in mind for the training of handicapped persons.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. M. O'Leary) Michael O'Leary
Speaker.P: AnCO are already training handicapped persons who are suitable for the normal training provided by AnCO and have been referred to them by the placement officers of the National Rehabilitation Board. It is intended to continue and develop this practice.
Arising out of discussions with the National Rehabilitation Board, AnCO are investigating the need to establish an industrial rehabilitation unit.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Céibh Phort na bhFrancach.
MainHeading.P: 297. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil se ar intinn aige deontas a chur ar fáil le céibh a thógáil ag Port na bhFrancach, Béal an Mhuirthead, Contae Mhaigh Eo.

Speaker.hpid: Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Donnell) Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Donnell)
Speaker.P: Tuigim go bhfuil an cheist sin á breithniú ag an Aire Talmhaíochta agus Iascaigh.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Deontais Cholaistí Gaeilge.
MainHeading.P: 298. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil aon deontas á íoc le Coláistí Gaeilge atá taobh amuigh den Ghaeltacht agus, má tá, an inseoidh sé (a) cé mhéad coláistí atá i gceist agus (b) cé mhéad d'airgead na Gaeltachta atá á íoc leo.

Speaker.hpid: Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Donnell) Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Donnell)
Speaker.P: Íoctar deontais chun coláistí seanbhunaithe dá leithéid sin a dheisiú nó a fheabhsú. Ó 1967 i leith tá £13,800 íoctha le ceithre choláiste.
Tá deontais á lorg ag coláistí mar sin i leith foghlaimeoirí a bhíonn ag freastal orthu ach níor tugadh aon chinneadh ar an iarratas sin go fóill.

asked the Minister for Health if he will review the arrangements made between his Department and the authorities of St. Joseph's Unit, Our Lady's Hospice, Harold's Cross, Dublin, which limited rehabilitation to geriatric cases over 65 years of age, in view of the fact that the hospice has now been developed along modern lines as an active rehabilitation centre dealing mainly with rheumatological disorders and the average age of patients is 50 to 55 years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The original arrangement for St. Joseph's Unit, Our Lady's Hospice, was that rehabilitation would be limited to persons over 65 years. It was recently stated in connection with a proposal for extra staff for the unit, that the average age of patients being treated in the unit is 50-55 years.

The advice of the National Rehabilitation Board was sought on the matter and the reply of the board was received in my Department on 18th July, 1973. The reply is being considered and I expect that my review of the arrangement will be completed very shortly.
